verses.text: Now the people complained in the hearing of the LORD about their hardships. When the LORD heard it, his anger burned, and fire from the LORD blazed among them and consumed some outside the camp.
verses.comment: Direct translation of 'complained', some versions say 'murmured'.

verses.text: Then the people cried out to Moses, and Moses prayed to the LORD, and the fire died down.
verses.comment: Prayer as the means to stop the judgment, matching the sense of the original.

verses.text: So that place was called Taberah, because the fire of the LORD had burned among them.
verses.comment: "Taberah" means 'burning' in Hebrew; noted for clarity.

verses.text: The mixed multitude among them began to crave other food. The Israelites also started to weep again and said, "Who will give us meat to eat?"
verses.comment: 'Mixed multitude' is a direct rendering of the Hebrew ('asaphsuph').

verses.text: "We remember the fish we ate in Egypt free of charge, the cucumbers, the melons, the leeks, the onions, and the garlic."
verses.comment: Food items listed according to original text; 'free of charge' refers to 'for nothing'.

verses.text: "But now our strength is dried up, and there is nothing at all except this manna to look at."
verses.comment: 'Strength is dried up' is literal translation of Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Now the manna was like coriander seed, and its color was like bdellium.
verses.comment: Bdellium: a resin, color described in ancient sources as white.

verses.text: The people went about, gathered it, ground it in mills or crushed it in mortars, boiled it in pots and made cakes of it. And its taste was like cakes baked with oil.
verses.comment: Retained original food preparation methods.

verses.text: When the dew fell upon the camp at night, the manna fell upon it.
verses.comment: Literal rendering.

verses.text: Moses heard the people weeping throughout their families, everyone at the entrance to his tent. The anger of the LORD blazed greatly, and Moses was displeased.
verses.comment: Maintained the emphatic language of God's anger.

verses.text: So Moses said to the LORD, "Why have you treated your servant badly? Why have I not found favor in your sight, that you placed the burden of all this people on me?"
verses.comment: 'Favor in your sight' translates 'chen', meaning grace/favor.

verses.text: "Did I conceive all this people? Did I give birth to them, that you should tell me, 'Carry them in your arms, as a nurse carries a baby,' to the land you promised to their ancestors?"
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Moses’s complaint.

verses.text: "Where am I to get meat to give to all these people? For they weep before me, saying, 'Give us meat to eat!'"
verses.comment: Direct expression of Moses's distress.

verses.text: "I am not able to carry all this people alone; the burden is too heavy for me."
verses.comment: Represents Moses’s emotional state literally.

verses.text: "If you will treat me like this, please kill me at once—if I have found favor in your sight—that I may not see my own wretchedness."
verses.comment: ‘Wretchedness’ translates 'ra' meaning misery.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, "Gather for me seventy men from the elders of Israel, whom you know to be elders and officers of the people. Bring them to the tent of meeting, and let them stand there with you."
verses.comment: 'Tent of meeting' rendered for clarity.

verses.text: "I will come down and speak with you there. I will take some of the Spirit who is on you and put it on them, and they shall help you bear the burden of the people, so you do not carry it alone."
verses.comment: 'Spirit' refers to God's Spirit; matches Hebrew 'ruach'.

verses.text: "And say to the people, 'Consecrate yourselves for tomorrow, and you will eat meat, for you have wept in the hearing of the LORD, saying, 'Who will give us meat to eat? For it was better for us in Egypt.' Therefore the LORD will give you meat, and you shall eat.'"
verses.comment: ‘Consecrate yourselves’ (Heb. ‘hitkadashu’) retained.

verses.text: "You shall not eat it for one day, or two days, or five days, or ten days, or twenty days,"
verses.comment: The list is retained for emphasis as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: "but for a whole month, until it comes out of your nostrils and becomes loathsome to you, because you have rejected the LORD who is among you and have wept before him, saying, 'Why did we come out of Egypt?'"
verses.comment: Phrase 'comes out your nostrils' is literal.

verses.text: But Moses said, "The people among whom I am number six hundred thousand on foot, and you have said, 'I will give them meat, that they may eat a whole month!'"
verses.comment: 'Six hundred thousand on foot' matches original enumeration.

verses.text: "Will flocks and herds be slaughtered for them, and be enough for them? Or will all the fish of the sea be gathered for them, and be enough for them?"
verses.comment: Moses questioning God's ability in literal manner.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses, "Is the LORD’s hand shortened? Now you shall see whether my word will come true for you or not."
verses.comment: 'Hand shortened' is Hebrew idiom for 'lack of power.'

verses.text: So Moses went out and told the people the words of the LORD. He gathered seventy men from the elders of the people and had them stand around the tent.
verses.comment: Plain, literal statement.

verses.text: Then the LORD came down in the cloud and spoke to him, and he took some of the Spirit that was on Moses and put it on the seventy elders. When the Spirit rested on them, they prophesied, but they did not continue doing it.
verses.comment: "Did not continue" replaces a rare Hebrew idiom meaning 'they did not do it again.'

verses.text: Two men, named Eldad and Medad, had remained in the camp. They were listed among the elders, but had not gone out to the tent. The Spirit rested on them, and they prophesied in the camp.
verses.comment: Names 'Eldad and Medad' transliterated from Hebrew.

verses.text: A young man ran and told Moses, "Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp!"
verses.comment: Retains excitement of Hebrew narrative.

verses.text: Joshua the son of Nun, Moses's assistant since youth, said, "My lord Moses, stop them!"
verses.comment: Joshua's relationship clarified as 'assistant since youth'.

verses.text: But Moses said to him, "Are you jealous for my sake? Would that all the LORD’s people were prophets, and that the LORD would put his Spirit on them!"
verses.comment: 'Would that' is archaic, retained for faithfulness; means 'I wish'.

verses.text: Then Moses and the elders of Israel returned to the camp.
verses.comment: Plain, direct translation.

verses.text: Now a wind went out from the LORD and brought quail from the sea. It let them fall beside the camp, about a day’s journey on either side, all around the camp, and about two cubits deep on the ground.
verses.comment: Two cubits = approximately three feet.

verses.text: The people rose all that day, and all night, and all the next day, and gathered the quail—those who gathered least gathered ten homers. And they spread them out for themselves all around the camp.
verses.comment: One homer = about 6 bushels. Measurement retained from Hebrew.

verses.text: While the meat was still between their teeth, before it was chewed, the anger of the LORD burned against the people, and the LORD struck them with a very severe plague.
verses.comment: Strong language retained as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So that place was called Kibroth-hattaavah, because there they buried the people who had been greedy.
verses.comment: 'Kibroth-hattaavah' means 'graves of craving.'

verses.text: From Kibroth-hattaavah the people journeyed to Hazeroth, and they remained at Hazeroth.
verses.comment: Place names transliterated as per original text.
